Award.AwardTitle: The Open Cyber Challenge Platform For Teaching Information Assurance, Cyber Security, and Forensics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project creates an open-source cyber challenge software platform (OCCP) and accompanying educational and assessment materials that are designed to be widely disseminated for teaching high school and college information assurance, cyber security, and digital forensics courses. The project consists of activities to design the OCCP using free/low cost virtualization software packaged in a standard way for public release; to create instances of the OCCP for network defense courses, penetration testing courses, and secure programming courses; to create supplemental educational materials for use with the OCCP instances in these courses; to assess the effectiveness of the use of OCCP in these courses; and to hold workshops and create a web portal for wide dissemination of educational materials, and for community contributions to the OCCP.

The result of this project represents a controlled teaching and assessment environment where students apply information assurance, cyber security, and digital forensics concepts in orchestrated pedagogically-sound realistic scenarios. The OCCP is easy and inexpensive to install and as such provides a starting point that instructors can deploy to save substantial effort, and yet still tailor to their specific needs. Furthermore, it provides a framework with a software architecture and "packaging" that is meant to be shared, modified, extended, and re-used to facilitate the development of an open source community that uses, supports, and extends the OCCP.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals Of The Project. The goals of the project were to increase the number of qualified students entering cybersecurity fields and to broadly increase the capacity of U.S. higher education to produce professionals in these fields by creating a free, open-source cyber challenge software platform and accompanying educational materials. This OCCP environment was designed to be a controlled teaching and assessment environment where students defend against known attacks orchestrated in pedagogically sound scenarios. The specific goals were:

  1. Create a platform that is configurable to a controlled environment that focuses on teaching and assessing students in specific cybersecurity concepts and skills.

  2. Create a platform that is itself free, and is also reasonable in terms of cost of required hardware, and in terms of required technical installation and maintenance expertise.

  3. Create a platform that facilitates additions and extensions by the educational community.

  4. Perform a formal assessment of the effectiveness of the resulting OCCP-based materials for cybersecurity educational goals.

  5. Widely disseminate the resulting OCCP and educational materials to high schools and colleges.

Outcomes.

  • Cyber Platform Survey Report. The project studied the existing cyber challenge platforms at its inception in 2013. The University of Rhode Island (URI) Technical Report “Cyber Challenges in 2013” was published in 2014. It described cyber challenge platforms such as XNet, The US Cyber Range, SANS Netwars, the U.S. Cyber Challenge, CyberNexs, and CyberPatriot. It described how these cyber challenge platforms were configured and what their limitiations for general use were including: being restricted to government use, prohibitively expensive, or too special-purpose.

  • OCCP Platform. The OCCP was released for Alpha testing (a few organizations that provided detailed feedback) in Year 2, and Beta testing (public dissemination with feedback) in Year 3, and final public release in Year 4. It is available at:

    • OCCP Portal: https://opencyberchallenge.net/

    • Github: https://github.com/OpenCyberChallengePlatform

  • Scenarios. To seed community development, the OCCP portal has several example scenarios developed on the project:  in Network Defense,  in Incident Response/Forensics, and  in Penetration Testing. The scenarios were tested in URI Graduate Cybersecurity courses, courses at New England Technical college, and in a high school cyber competition conducted in Rhode Island in Year 3. The scenarios are available on the OCCP Web portal.

  • Educational Assessments. To help educators use the OCCP in academics, the OCCP team enlisted a faculty member from the URI School of Education to produce an assessment template for cyber challenges. An instance of this was used in several URI Graduate cybersecurity courses. The assessment template and guidance are available on the OCCP portal.

  • Dissemination and Community Building. The OCCP is predicated on open source model of support where it is supported by the community both contributing to the platform itself, and also contributing scenarios and educational materials. The Forum on the OCCP portal page and the GitHub contribution mechanism is the core of the open source support for OCCP. In addition to the online dissemenination, the OCCP was presented at a NIST NICE workshop in 2015, had its own dedicated workshop in 2017 (https://opencyberchallenge.net/workshop), and is being scheduled for a CAE webinar in late 2017/early 2018. 142 organizations downloaded the Beta version in Year 3 with over 200 having obtained it by the conclusion of the project.

Summary of Outcomes.

Intellectual Merit. The project produced the OCCP, which is a controlled teaching and assessment environment where students apply cybersecurity concepts in orchestrated pedagogically-sound realistic scenarios. The OCCP is free open-source software that provides a starting point that instructors and trainers can deploy to save substantial effort, and yet still tailor to their specific needs. Its architecture uses a novel design (detailed at https://opencyberchallenge.net/wiki) that packages it to facilitate sharing, modification, extension, and reuse. The project produced an assessment component, developed with education experts, that addresses the fact that most cyber challenges have not provided formal feedback as to their educational effectiveness – feedback that is essential to shape the modifications for improved teaching that the OCCP is designed to allow.

Broader Impact. The OCCP has the potential to enhance cyber security education in the U.S. by providing exciting relevant cyber challenge experiences, which have a proven record in government training and specialized challenge events, to a much wider audience. The OCCP instances and associated materials developed on the project are a proof of concept that the OCCP is suitable for high school and college-level cyber security courses. They also serve as seed examples to assist others in the community in developing and contributing their own OCCP-based teaching materials for others to use. The OCCP's design that is itself free, and is also reasonable in terms of cost of required software/hardware and in terms of required technical installation/maintenance expertise, make its use feasible in a broad range of educational institutions. The OCCP portals facilitate its extensive dissemination to support cybersecurity education throughout the country.
